body.name: Escape from a Video Game: The Complete Series
body.merchantInfo: Sold by Olivia-Products and Fulfilled by Amazon.
editorialReviews: Editorial Reviews About the Author Dustin Brady writes funny, action-packed books for kids. Although he regularly gets locked out of his own accounts for forgetting passwords, Dustin still remembers the Super Mario Bros. 3 game genie code for infinite lives. It’s SLXPLOVS. Dustin lives in Cleveland, Ohio, with his wife, kids, and a small dog named Nugget.

body.description: This box set is the only way to own the complete Escape from a Video Game series plus The Lost Files, an exclusive bonus adventure! Each pick-your-plot story drops young readers into a different video game to defeat monsters, solve mysteries, and outsmart supervillains.The follow-up to the bestselling Trapped in a Video Game series puts the controller in your hands. Choose where to explore, when to attack, and who to trust as you uncover the secrets buried deep within each game. Once you finish the three main adventures, check out The Lost Files, in-print and illustrated for the first time, for one final showdown with the ultimate villain.Book One: The Secret of Phantom IslandTrek to a mysterious island as Cooper Hawke, the greatest treasure hunter the world has ever known. As you battle strange creatures, solve ancient puzzles, and unlock hidden areas, you’ll discover that Phantom Island is keeping secrets far more sinister than anyone could have imagined. Book Two: Mystery on the Starship CrusaderJoin eight strangers inside of a video game for a chance to win a million dollars. Survive to the end, and you’re rich. There’s just one problem: a traitor is hiding among your group. This whodunnit space adventure is perfect for fans of Among Us.Book Three: The EndgameOne hundred villains will enter Grim Island, but only one will be crowned the Greatest Supervillain of All Time. Will it be you? Fortnite fans will fall in love with this battle royale adventure’s frenetic pace and quirky humor.Bonus Book: The Lost FilesThe Lost Files unlocks each book’s secret adventure to take you on a wild ride that leads to the ultimate villain of the series. This newly illustrated collection of stories, previously only available online, provides a satisfying conclusion to the Escape from a Video Game saga.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars My 5/6 year old loves it.
reviews.reviewText: I had “Which Way” and “choose your own adventure” books when I was a kid. This is like that with modern subject matter. It’s fun. Great box set. Heavyweight quality paper.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Got my struggling reader engaged!
reviews.reviewText: My 5th grade son has struggled with reading for years and always said it was boring. He loves gaming so I bought Trapped in and then Escape from a Video Game.He loved them so much and even thought they are below his age, they were chapter books so he didn’t really notice! The ease of reading helping him fall in love with reading and now he frequently sits with me to read.If you have a gamer kid, they’ll love it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great set of books!
reviews.reviewText: If you can get an active 4th grader to read, they must be good! Kids are so caught up with video games, so if it can get them excited to read, it’s a win-win deal! Good price for the set!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great present for 10 yr old boy

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2024
reviews.reviewText: My 11 year old loves these books. We read them together and have enjoyed finding the secret message.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars 11 year old loves
reviews.reviewText: Gave these to my son for Christmas and he has loved them so far! He’s almost 12

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2023
Reviewed in the United States on December 20, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars The first book was great, the others not so much
reviews.reviewText: When my son started reading, he couldn't put it down. He loved being able to choose the actions in the first book. The second book had some options to choose, but also required a lot of flipping through every page to look for a specific symbol. He quickly got frustrated with that. The other two books didn't really have interactive components. It seemed like they were written quickly to make a set. Overall, my son enjoyed them enough to read them all. If they were all like the first, I would have highly recommended them. It was very disappointing that the best part of the books didn't continue through the whole set.

Our 10 year old likes to read but struggles to find books that interest him. He stumbled on the book set from the previous series and fell in love. It’s nice to see him devouring this second set of books!

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent box set, but was opened on arrival so reason for 4 star.
reviews.reviewText: Looks like a decent box set.. but plastic was opened and it was to be a gift so had to return, as can’t gift something opened!

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent, but not as great as the first series
reviews.reviewText: While my son doesn't dislike these books, he is definitely not enjoying them nearly as much as the Trapped in a Video Game series of books. The original series he literally couldn't put down and he has read them several times, so he was super excited to see there was a new series of books. Unfortunately, they were not what he was expecting. He wanted straight up books like the previous series, but these new books are full of puzzles that have to be solved in order to read the story, so he was super disappointed. He just wanted books that he could read from cover-to-cover as a way to relax. Instead, he found these books a bit frustrating because he felt the puzzles took away from the actual story line.
